docs.lead_paragraph: Brian treglio lies on his stomach on a mat, part of a circle of troubled New York City youths in a theater group called Faces. He's about to go first in ''Intimate Moments,'' an exercise that the others know well: their leader, a social worker named Susan Montez, has often used it to draw them closer together, as well as to bring forth experience that is ''real'' -- heartfelt and serious -- on a subject of concern. The joke is that they've all done Intimate Moments so many times, people have started to cheat, to tell an intimate story for the second or third time. But today that's less likely, and one reason is that the subject is grave. Dating violence is something Faces has never really succeeded in talking about. And the story Brian Treglio is about to tell is one that will change the way they all think about him.

headline.main: The Film Makers and the Abuser

docs.abstract: Ted Conover article on making of documentary film It Ain't Love on teen-age dating violence; film makers Andy Young and Susan Todd worked with Faces, New York City youth theater group, whose members revealed own experiences as abusers and abuse sufferers; group member Brian Treglio, who exposed own behavior, questions wisdom of move; photos (L)
